awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer Research Experience for Undergraduates in Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.  This is a ten-week summer residential research participation experience that engages undergraduate students in full-time active research collaborations with faculty, research professionals, and graduate students at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. A selection of research projects in Physics, Applied Physics, and Astronomy, as well as closely associated areas, is available. Students will gain experience in presenting their results by making oral and written presentations throughout the summer. This project impacts the research and development competitiveness of the United States by recruiting excellent students into STEM research fields and by training these students to perform leading-edge research in technologically important fields. 

Undergraduate students are both mentored individually by research faculty and engage in group professional development activities. Research projects are cutting-edge in Physics, Applied Physics, and Astronomy, and include astronomy, astrophysics, condensed matter physics, energy conversion, geophysics, particle physics, and biological physics. In addition to their own research area, students will be exposed to a variety of research topics and methodologies through a series of research seminars and student presentations. Further breadth will be developed through visits to nearby research facilities. To assist in their professional development, students also participate in tutorials on ethics, applying to graduate school, scientific writing and giving scientific presentations, as well as safety training, machine shop training, and lab tours.  These activities allow students to put their research experience into a wider perspective, build a network of professional contacts, and develop professional skills in a scientific environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
All of the students participating in the NSF REU Program in Physics from June-August, 2022 were able to engage in work that led to a professional-quality research symposium presentation at the end of the summer. A summary of projects is: 

Stevenson, Paige, Machine Learning Applications for Materials Science: Predicting Properties of Two-dimensional Magnetic Materials, Advisor- Rhone

Abstract: We trained successful neural networks to predict the formation energy and magneticmoment of 2-dimensional ferromagnetic materials of similar structure to Cr2Ge2Te6. We collectelemental data on materials with known and unknown properties from easily accessible sourcesto screen for viable materials for use in future research. We predicted the properties of 1225 materials that arecandidates for further research in two-dimensional magnetism and identify several potentialsources of error in our models that can be targeted for further improvement.

Ruiter, David, Chemical Applications of Time-Dependent Density Functional Theory, Advisor- Lakshmi

Abstract: Density Functional Theory (DFT) can be used to determine the properties of molecules including single-point energy, hyperfine couplings, charge and spin density. Time-dependent computations can be used to predict excited states and transition energies. We examined theproperties of porphine, tetraphenyl porphyrin (TPP), magnesium porphyrin (Mg-Por), and magnesium tetraphenyl porphyrin (Mg-TPP).

McPherson, Hannah, Simulating Soliton Behavior in Elastic Collisions, Advisor- N'Gom

Abstract: An investigation into the three mainproperties of light, amplitude,  phase, and polarity,were undertaken, followed by an introduction to Spatial Light Modulator (SLM) devices and their many uses within the context of optics experiments. Soliton behavior was investigated through a series of computational algorithms modeled within a system of (2+1) dimensions that contains a pair of solitons on a path towards collision.

Byrge, Noah, Molecular Dynamics of Two-dimensional Allotropes of Carbon, Advisor- Meunier

Abstract: We developed approaches to design an automated process to relax large quantities of proposed carbon structures.To do this we used LAMMPS (Large-scaleAtomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator) in conjunction with a python script to relax large quantities of structures and convert the resulting files to cif format with ASE. 

Callan, Madeleine, Density Functional Theory of Porphyrin+ and Mg-Porphyrin+ Cations, Advisor- Lakshmi

Abstract: At the atomic scale, in a system of N particles, the energies that exist between them is the starting point of density functional theory (DFT) as an approximation method to solve the Schrödinger equation. Density functional theory calculations were carriedout to describe molecules and their properties using ORCA code. We determined the single point energy, and hyperfine couplings (HFC) of the nitrogens in Porphyrin and Mg-Porphyrin cations , as well as their electron and spin densities.

Nambisan, Maya, Computational Analysis of Porphyrin Models, Advisor- Lakshmi

Abstract: Porphyrins are able to facilitate the transfer of electrons and energy as well as the transportof oxygen in numerous essential biomolecules. Naturally occurring porphyrins such as the ones inthese biomolecules are known to havefourpyrrole groups containing nitrogen. Numerous studied have shown that synthetically modified porphyrins also have a number of use properties such asvariable redox potentials. In light of that information, the persistence of the four nitrogen pyrrole groups in naturally occurring porphyrins is of particular interest. This study analysed the structuresof a variety of both naturally occurring as well as synthetic porphyrins using computationalmethods such as Density Functional Theory.

Gruszecki, Elijah, Computational Analysis of Iron Sulfur Clusters in Proteins, Advisor- Lakshmi

Abstract: Iron-Sulfur clusters exist in a wide variety of biological systems as metal sites in charge transfer. Compared to the other two types of metal sites, they have amuch wider variety in redox potential, indicating a high degree of tunability. Additionally, [4Fe-4S] clusters are present inType I photosynthetic reaction centers, and as such study of them can greatly improve our understanding of photosynthesis. In this study, we utilized density functional theory to examine properties of simple iron-sulfur clusters with the end goal of applying these techniques to the larger and more complex systems in Type I reactions centers of interest.
